questions.text: True about following instrument is:

choices.text: Used to hold soft tissue like bowel
Used to hold tough tissue like Skin and Fascia

questions.solution:
The given image is of Lister’s sinus forceps.

It is used for blunt dissection during "Hilton's method" of abscess drainage to break the bacterial loculli. It is commonly used for inserting or removing packing in the sinus cavity.

The image of lister's forceps is given below.

 

Option B: Hemostatic forceps

The image below shows a hemostatic forceps that has serrated blade, with a handle lock.

Option c : Babcock's forceps is used to hold soft tissue like Bowel, Fallopian tube, Appendix, Ureter, Cord, etc. The image is given below.

Option d : Allis' tissue forceps is used to hold skin flaps, fascias, fibrous tissue, aponeurosis, galea, and bladder wall. Delicate structures like bowel or vessel walls are avoided due to the risk of tear. So, Allis' forceps can be used to hold fascia and galea aponeurotica in craniotomy, to hold skin flaps & bladder wall and to hold the vaginal wall during hysterectomy. The image is shown below.

questions.text: A 46-year old lady is being evaluated for abnormal uterine bleeding by a dilatation and curettage procedure. The following instruments are placed on a table in the minor operating theatre. Which of the following instruments will be used in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Among the given instruments 1, 2, and 3 - Sim's uterine curette, Hegar's dilators, and Simpson's uterine sound are used for dilatation and curettage (D&C).

Instruments used in D&C:

  • Sim’s speculum: It retracts the posterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix
  • Anterior vaginal wall retractor: Retracts the anterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix.
  • Vulsellum or Allis forceps: To hold the anterior lip of the cervix
  • Uterine sound: Simpson's uterine sound is a 30 cm long angulated instrument with a handle at one end and a rounded blunt tip at the other.
    It is used to measure the length of the uterus. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement
  • Cervical dilators: 
    • Hegar's dilator is a double-ended dilator used to dilate the cervix.
    • Hawkins’ single-ended dilator 
    • Fenton’s dilator
  • Curette:
    • Sim's curette is a single-ended curette
    • Blake's curette is a double-ended curette

Other options: 

Karman's cannula: It is used for menstrual regulation. 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula and Rubin's cannula are used in hysterosalpingography.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Image shows Babcock’s forceps where:

  • Distal part of distal blade is curved with a triangular fenestra which allows soft tissues to bulge out.
  • Tip is non traumatic with transverse serrations on it.
  • It has got a lock in proximal part.

Uses:

  • Hold any part of Bowel, Fallopian tube, Appendix, Ureter, Cord etc.

Option A: Allis tissue forceps

  • Distal blades are not opposing each other
  • Tip has got teeth in each blade which are opposing
  • Lock in proximal part

Uses:

  • Hold Skin flaps, Fascia, Aponeurosis, Bladder wall.

Option C: Lane’s tissue holding forceps

  • It has got stout and thick distal blades with oval fenestra in each blade
  • Apposing tooth in the tip
  • Lock in proximal part

Uses:

  • Hold bulky and tough structures, hold lymph nodes.

Option D: Kocher’s hemostatic forceps

Apposing tooth in the tip and serrations in the distal blades.

Uses:

  • Hold pedicles, tough structures, cut ends of muscles
  • Hold ribs during rib dissection, hold gauze for blunt dissection, hold resected bowel.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Auvard speculum. It retracts the posterior vaginal wall during vaginal hysterectomy and is self retractory due to the circular structure on its handle which is heavy.

The image given below shows Sim's speculum.

The image given below shows Cusco's self retaining bivalved speculum.

questions.text: What is the size of the given blade used for incision and drainage of a superficial abscess?
questions.solution:
The blade shown in the image is of the size 11.

The 11-blade is used for skin incisions (eg. incision and drainage) and arteriotomy

The 22-blade is often used for abdominal incisions

15-blade for minor surgical procedures

questions.text: What is the main use of the instrument seen in the image?

choices.text: Reduction of the fracture of nasal septum
Reduction of the fracture of nasal bone
Punching out bone in DCR procedure

questions.solution:
The instrument seen in the image is Walsham forceps. Walsham is mainly used to reduce bone fracture.

Asch forceps is mainly used to reduce nasal septum.

questions.text: The type of laryngoscope blade shown in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Miller laryngoscopic blade.

Miller is a straight blade laryngoscope, used in:

  • Neonates, infants and young children
  • Adults with short thyromental distance and long floppy epiglottis.

Laryngoscopic blades can be

  • Straight blade, Miller
  • Curved blade, Macintosh

Advantage of curved blade:

  • Greater room available for the passage for an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth

questions.text: Identify the obstetric device given in the image below.
questions.solution:
The obstetric device given in the image above is of cervidil vaginal insert.

Cervidil vaginal insert is a thin, flat, rectangular polymeric wafer held within a small, white mesh polyester sac. It contains 10 mg of dinoprostone (PGE2) released at a rate of 0.3 mg/hour. The sac has a long attached tail to allow easy removal from the vagina.

Following insertion, the woman should remain recumbent for at least 2 hours. The insert is removed after 12 hours or with labour onset and at least 30 minutes before the administration of oxytocin. It is used for cervical ripening before induction. A possible side effect of dinoprostone is uterine tachysystole.

Other options :

Option A: The Lippes Loop is a first-generation intrauterine device (IUD) available in four sizes- A, B, C, and D. It is an S-shaped device, typically made of polyethene, with a tail made of fine nylon that extends into the vagina after insertion. While larger loops tend to have higher removal rates due to side effects, they offer stronger anti-fertility effects. Larger loops are generally recommended for multiparous women. The device contains a small amount of barium sulfate, which enables X-ray visualization.

The image of the Lippes loop is given below.

Option C: Misoprostol is a methyl ester of PGE1, used in the induction of labour and the management of postpartum haemorrhage. Side effects include fever, tachysystole (hyperstimulation), fetal heart rate changes and meconium passage. It should not be used for cases with previous cesarean birth because the risk of uterine rupture is high.

Option D: Mirena is a third-generation intrauterine contraceptive device, containing 52mg of levonorgestrel. Its approved life span is 5 years. Apart from contraception, it is used for the treatment of menorrhagia, endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, and dysmenorrhea secondary to endometriosis and adenomyosis.

The image of Mirena is given below.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Doyen’s mouth gag is used to keep the mouth open for intraoral surgery when retraction of the tongue is not required or desirable. Mostly used for tongue surgery. It is applied on one side of the mouth on molar teeth.

Option A: Doyen’s retractor is used to retract abdominal wall in abdominal and pelvic surgeries to expose field of operation.

Option C: Doyen’s intestinal occlusion clamp is used to for resection and anastomosis of intestine in case of

  • Strangulated hernia
  • Accidental injuries to the gut
  • Intestinal growths
  • Gastric/intestinal bypass surgeries

Option D: Joll’s thyroid retractor is a self-retaining retractor used in thyroid surgeries to retract skin.

questions.text: A surgeon while performing a laparotomy procedure uses the following instrument. Which of the following option is true about this instrument?

choices.text: Safer in procedures closer to vital structures

questions.solution:
The given instrument is Monopolar electrocautery. Both cutting and coagulation modes are possible with monopolar electrocautery.

  • Application of Low voltage, high amplitude, continuous waveforms is responsible for the cutting of tissues.
  • Application of High voltage current for a short duration(intermittent waveform) is responsible for the coagulating of tissues

A short circuit is established in bipolar electrocautery between the tips of the instrument. This makes the chances of burns lesser compared to monopolar electrocautery. Bipolar electrocautery has less lateral dissipation of current so it is safer in procedures closure to vital structures. Bipolar cautery can be seen in the image below.

Related Pearl: Diathermy/Cautery:

Features Monopolar Bipolar
Flow of current

Cautery pencil –> tissue –> cautery pad –> machine/ground

Hence more chance of burns

Only between tips of the instrument

Hence less chance of burns
Modes

Cutting – Low voltage, high amplitude, continuous waveforms

Coagulation – Alternate waveforms (Bursts)

Dessication – Low power

Fulguration – High power

 Only coagulation
Dissipation

More thermal dissipation of current

Hence can cause damage to nerves and other vital structures

Less lateral dissipation of current

Hence safer in procedures closer to vital structures

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the image below:
questions.solution: The image given is of Morris Retractor, which is a big retractor useful for giving maximum exposure in large incisions such as those used in the abdomen. It can be used to improve visibility on one side of an incision (by pulling firmly in that direction); so is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady who had tested positive for HPV  is undergoing an investigation where the following device is used. Which of the following statements is false about this investigation?

choices.text: It is used in lithotomy position
Green filter is used to study vascular pattern
External os is visualised at a distance of 50 cm

questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a colposcope. It is used to perform colposcopy where the cervix is visualized at a distance of around 20 cm with the patient in the lithotomy position.

This instrument provides binocular vision with a magnification of 6x-15x. A green filter is used to study vascular pattern as the vessels appear black. Abnormal areas can be identified by their peculiar vascular pattern such as mosaic, reticular, and punctate.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is Rubins cannula.

It is used in hysterosalpingogram recording; while the dye is instilled into the uterine cavity, the cone prevents retrograde spills into the vagina.

Spackman Cannula allows for the intra-operative manipulation of both anteverted and retroverted uterus as well as facilitating quick, simple, effective hysterosalpingogram for tubal patency studies.

Other options:

Option A: Karman's cannula is a flexible, plastic suction cannula used for manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) in early pregnancy termination or uterine evacuation. It is commonly used with a syringe for safe, low-risk procedures in gynaecological care. The image is given below.

Option B: Spackman’s cannula is a specialized uterine cannula used for tubal patency tests and hysterosalpingography (HSG). It helps deliver contrast media or dye into the uterine cavity to assess fallopian tube blockage.

Option C: A menstrual regulation syringe is a manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) device used for early uterine evacuation before pregnancy confirmation. It is commonly used in reproductive health care to regulate menstruation safely and effectively.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows rectal temperature probe.

Other options:

NAVA catheter-

Here NAVA is Neurally Adjusted Ventilatory Assist is a mode of mechanical ventilation.

Swan Ganz Catheter / Pulmonary artery catheter – Right Heart Catheterization

questions.text: What is the needle shown in the picture ?
questions.solution:
This is the image of a Tuohy needle that is used to provide epidural anesthesia. It can be recognized by its curved (Huber) tip and the markings made at 1 cm intervals along its length.

Other options: 

Options A and B: The image below shows spinal needles are long thin needles that are classified based on their tip into: 

  • Cutting needles: Quincke-Babcock, Pitkin
  • Pencil tip needles: Whitacre and Sprotte

Option D: The instrument below is the Quincke Needle used in spinal anesthesia.

questions.text: Identify the Catheter:
questions.solution:
Malecot Catheter is a self retaining Urinary Catheter with umbrella or flower tip.

  • It contains sulphur hence is radioopaque.
  • It is never introduced per urethrally.
  • It is sterilized by boiling.

Uses:

  • Suprapubic cystostomy
  • Perinephric abscess
  • Pyonephrosis
  • Cabot’s nephrostomy
  • Subphrenic abscess
  • Cholecystotomy
  • Infected pseudocyst of pancreas
  • Amoebic liver abscess
  • Gastrostomy

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below.
questions.solution:
The image is that of a Hasson trocar which is used in the open method of creating pneumoperitoneum.

There are two methods used for the creation of a pneumoperitoneum:

  1. Closed method
  2. Open method

The open method is preferred for patients who have undergone previous abdominal surgeries as the small bowel may be adherent to the undersurface of the abdominal wound. The use of the open technique for creating a pneumoperitoneum avoids the morbidity related to a blind puncture.

To achieve this, a 1 cm vertical or transverse incision is made at the level of the umbilicus, stay sutures are applied, and the fascia is dissected. Free penetration into the abdominal cavity is confirmed by the gentle introduction of a finger. A Hasson trocar (shown below) is inserted and anchored, and a pneumoperitoneum is created. This is the Hasson or modified Hasson approach. 

The closed method using the Veress needle has a small but significant potential for intestinal or vascular injury on the introduction of the needle or trocar. Proper placement of the needle can be determined by the inability to re-aspirate injected saline. The normal insufflation rate is 4-6 litres/min.

The image below shows a Veress needle.

questions.text: Name of the instrument is ________
questions.solution:
Image shows Kocher’s thyroid dissector which is used during a thyroidectomy to dissect the upper pole of the thyroid.

The instrument is blunt and therefore damage to the superior thyroid artery or external laryngeal nerve is unlikely.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child diagnosed with bronchial asthma requires bronchodilator therapy. Which of the following device will you prescribe for this child, to avoid oropharyngeal adverse effects?
questions.solution:
The device in image 3 is a spacer device that can be prescribed to decrease the incidence of propellant-mediated oropharyngeal adverse effects.

Spacers reduce the velocity and size of particles entering the upper airways. This reduces the amount of drug depositing in the oropharynx and increases the proportion of drugs inhaled into the lower airways. Thus, a less amount of the drug gets swallowed and absorbed from the GI tract and limits local side effects. 

Spacer devices are useful in delivering inhaled drugs to children who are not able to use a pMDI alone but can also be used by adults for better drug delivery. The image below shows the use of a spacer device with a face mask which is preferred in children younger than 3 years of age.

 

The various devices used for the delivery of inhalational drugs are:

Pressurized metered-dose inhalers (pMDI) - Drugs are propelled from a canister in the pMDI with the aid of a propellant. These devices are convenient, portable, and can deliver 50–200 doses of a drug.

Image 1 in the question stem shows a pressurized metered-dose inhaler.

 

Dry powder inhalers - these devices scatter the drug into a fine powder that is dispersed by air turbulence on inhalation. DPIs have been developed to deliver drugs such as insulin, but the dosing is inconsistent. Children below 7 years find it difficult to use a DPI. 

Image 2 in the question stem shows a dry powder inhaler.

 

Nebulizers: Two types of nebulizer are available -

  • Jet nebulizers that are driven by a stream of gas (air or oxygen)
  • Ultrasonic nebulizers that use a rapidly vibrating piezoelectric crystal and thus do not require a source of compressed gas.

The nebulizers deliver much higher drug doses as compared pMDIs. These are useful in:

  • Treating acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD
  • Extreme airway obstruction (severe COPD)
  • Delivering inhaled drugs to infants and small children who cannot use the other inhalation devices
  • Administering drugs such as antibiotics in relatively high doses

Image 4 in the question stem shows a nebulizer.

questions.text: Identify the suture material.
questions.solution:
Plain catgut is yellowish absorbable suture material.

Chromic catgut is brownish.

Option A: Vicryl is violet colored absorbable suture material.

Option D: Silk is black colored, multifilament, natural, braided, and non absorbable suture material derived from cocoon of silkworm larva.

questions.text: What is the use of the instrument given below?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of a Leech-Wilkinson cannula. It is used to inject dye in hysterosalpingography. 

The following images show the cannula placed in the cervix for the procedure:

Other cannula used for the same purpose is the Rubin’s cannula which is shown below:

The image given below is the myomectomy screw.

questions.text: A G3P2 woman started to bleed profusely after expulsion of the placenta.  In spite of medical management, she was bleeding profusely.  The obstetrician used the instrument given in the picture as a mechanical method to control PPH.  Identify________
questions.solution:
The diagram given above depicts a Bakri balloon.  When medical management fails to control PPH, mechanical methods can be tried. 

  • A Bakri postpartum balloon may be inserted and inflated to tamponade the endometrial cavity.

questions.text: Identify the instrument commonly used in obstetrics?
questions.solution:
Episiotomy scissor

The angulation in the scissor is to prevent extension of pelvic tear into the anal margins and obstetretic anal sphincter injuries / complete perineal tear.

Structures cut in episiotomy:

  • Vaginal mucosa
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, levator ani muscles.
  • Internal pudendal blood vessels
  • Subcutaneous tissue and perineal skin

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Veress needle is used to produce pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgery.

 

Insufflation of the abdomen is accomplished with a Veress needle held at its serrated collar with the thumb and forefinger.
Because the linea alba is fused to the umbilicus, the abdominal wall is grasped with fingers or penetrating towel clip to elevate the abdominal wall away from the underlying structures. (As shown above)

Option A: Aneurysm needle (shown below) is used to catch small vessels and nerves.

Option C: Tracheal dilator is used to keep tracheostomy open.

Option D: Urethral dilator is used to dilate urethra.

questions.text: The instrument given in the image is?
questions.solution:
The given image is of Jackson Pratt Drain.

Jackson Pratt drains are often placed in wounds during surgery to prevent the collection of fluid underneath the incision site. This is a closed, air-tight drainage system which operates by self-suction. The drain(s) promote healing by keeping excess pressure off the incision and decreasing the risk of infection. The drain is sutured (stitched) in place at the skin at the site of insertion to promote stability.

There are two main parts to a JP drain:

  • a hollow tube
  • a collection bulb

The drain should be emptied as often as possible so that the bulb can be compressed fully to maintain suction. In general, this is usually done every four to six hours the first few days until the amount decreases.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Fuller’s tracheostomy tube.

It consists of an outer tube and an inner tube, the latter being slightly longer. Outer tube is made of two blades, which when pressed together, can be easily introduced into the tracheostomy opening. Inner tube has a hole in the centre so that patient can still have a chance to breathe from the larynx even when tube is blocked at its outer end.

Other options:

Option A: Cuffed tracheostomy tube:

Option B: Laryngeal mask airway

Option D: Jackson’s tracheostomy tube:

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: The following instrument is used for:
questions.solution:
Myringotomy is done by a sharp myringotome as shown in the image. Myringotome is a surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum.

 

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the posteroinferior or anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: The instrument given below is used in ?
questions.solution:
Image shows kehr’s T tube with vertical and horizontal limb, it is used post choledochotomy.

Post choledochotomy (after exploration of CBD), the horizontal limb of Kehr's T tube is placed in CBD and vertical limb is brought out as drain as shown in the image below.

It allows bile to drain while the sphincter of Oddi is in spasm postoperatively. Once the sphincter relaxes, bile drains normally down the bile duct and into the duodenum.
Common bile duct T-tubes should remain in for 10 days. The 10-day period is required to minimise the risk of biliary peritonitis after removal. However, once the T-tube cholangiogram has shown that there is free flow of bile into the duodenum and that there are no retained stones, some surgeons like to clamp the T-tube prior to removal.

questions.text: Which among the following is false about the procedure performed with this instrument ?

choices.text: Procedure is done with minimal cervical dilatation
Procedure is performed safely upto 14 weeks
Procedure can be done on an outpatient basis

questions.solution:
The image shows a Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA) Syringe. This is used to perform Manual Vaccum Aspiration (MVA) as a means of medical termination of pregnancy in the first trimester and is performed safely upto 12 weeks period of gestation with minimal cervical dilatation.

WHO recommends MVA upto 10 weeks POG (period of gestation) as procedure of choice.

It is a safe and simple procedure which is done on an outpatient basis. It can be done with local anaesthesia and is 98% effective. 

Other uses :

  • Incomplete abortion, Missed abortion
  • Molar Pregnancy
  • Blighted ovum
  • Endometrial aspiration.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows a Humby knife.

Humbys knife is used to harvest a split skin graft. The average thickness of the graft obtained from a Humbys knife is 0.3 mm.
